Dor. and Aeol. μᾶν-, ἡ, gen. μήνιος Pl. R. 390e, later μήνιδος Ael. Fr. 80, Them. Or. 22.265d, Jul. Or. 2.50b, AP 9.168 (Pall.):—

    1. wrath; from Hom. downwds. freq. of the wrath of the gods, Il. 5.34, al., A. Ag. 701 (lyr.), Pl. Lg. 880e, Men. 585; μῆνιν ἔχειν ἀπὸ θεοῦ Vett. Val. 184.3; μ. χθονίων Pi. P. 4.159; also of the dead worshipped as heroes, τοῖσι μ. κατέσκηψε Ταλθυβίου Hdt. 7.134, cf. 137; μ. τῶν τετελευτηκότων Pl. Hp.Ma. 282a; of injured parents, A. Ag. 155 (lyr.), Ch. 294; of suppliants, Id. Eu. 234, cf. E. Heracl. 762 (lyr.): but also, generally, of the wrath of Achilles, Il. 1.1, al., cf. Alc. Supp. 10.7; of the revengeful temper of a people, Hes. Sc. 21, Hdt. 7.229: c. gen. objecti, ὅτου . . μ. τοσήνδε πράγματος στήσας ἔχεις S. OT 699: in pl., Αἰήταο μήνιες A.R. 4.1205.
